THE FINE WINE MARKET – A YEAR IN REVIEW

In the second half of 2024, the global investment landscape exhibited notable resilience amid diverse economic conditions. The U.S. economy demonstrated robust growth, reminiscent of the 1980s, bolstered by business optimism and anticipated regulatory easing under the Trump administration.[1] This economic vigor contributed to a 24% surge in the S&P 500, driven by advancements in artificial intelligence and strong corporate earnings.[2] Conversely, Europe faced economic challenges, with political uncertainties and sluggish growth dampening investor sentiment.

One person’s loss can be another’s gain - this sentiment seems to be reflected in some trends within the market. Renewed confidence in the US and Asia based on increased investor wealth was highlighted in September when Acker auction house recorded their best regional result in Hong Kong for over two years.[3] With confidence growing and potential tax cuts looming under the Trump administration, the levels of disposable income amongst HNWs could well increase. Should that be the case, more wealth is likely to be channelled into fine wine.

Last year highlighted some stark differences in buyers’ attitudes based on their geographical location, with US Auction house Ackers Regional Wine Indices listing Burgundy as the top producing region with sales up 7.80%, and Italy second from bottom only above Bordeaux at -4.00%. These results showed a stark difference to the results posted by Liv-ex (UK based) with the Italy 100 performing better than any other sub-index of the Liv-ex 1000.

Burgundy prices have dropped and a large % of the buyers, be it auction or domestic, are coming from the US with Liv-ex stating the number of US buyers to have increased by over 9% year-to-date, highlighting the difference in buyer confidence. This international variation has been witnessed in-house with more international clients, covering 5 continents, coming on board in 2024 that previous years. Surely the continued geographical variation that we witnessed in 2024 will continue into 2025 making auction exit an ever-more attractive option. Taking the advice of experts to try and isolate the best performing components of any given index to limit any losses will give any investor the best chance of growth on whichever continent has the most buoyant economy at any given time.

Although the fine wine market in 2024 seemed to display overall price decline across all regions, investor activity when measured by country remains nuanced. Opportunities did arise for many with the arrival of a buyer’s market at the beginning of H2. The following breakdown provides some context as to the market conditions as they currently stand, as well as showcasing the highlights and events of the second half of this year…

H2 2024 Summary

JULY

  • Sotheby’s first ever exclusive single-owner Burgundy sale smashed records at the top of July 2024. 175 lots from wine and art collector Pierre Chen were sold, with more than a third of the lots sold achieving prices above their high estimates. Records were broken for the region of Beaune, such as a three-bottle lot of 2007 DRC Montrachet which sold for €15,800 per bottle – around 50% higher than the previous world record.[4]
  • Sine Qua Non entered centre stage at Christie’s online sale. More than 100 lots were listed, along with other Napa collections from Schrader Cellars and Heintz Cellar.[5]
  • 27-litre Bibi Graetz bottle takes record for most expensive bottle of Italian wine ever sold. The bottle of Colore 2016 sold for £87,104, smashing the previous record.[6]

AUGUST

  • The financial crash of Japan’s Nikkei 255, as well as other major stock indices swept through the global investment market.  Japan's Nikkei 225, a prominent stock index, closed down by 12.4%. Similarly, the Dow Jones Industrial Average futures dropped 444 points, or 1.11%, while S&P 500 and Nasdaq futures fell by 3% and 5.5%.[7]
  • Lebron James spent $100k on French wine following the Paris Olympics. Celebrating his team’s gold medal win, his drinking included US$40,000 of Champagne and US$32,000 of DRC alone.[8]
  • More than £5m was generated at a Sotheby’s Hong Kong Burgundy auction. Wines sold included 400 lots, 218 of which were an impressive array wines from Domain de la Romanée-Conti (DRC).[9]

SEPTEMBER

  1. A record breaking $15M auction from Acker takes the 6th spot for their top grossing auctions of all time. The wines sold, all from The Collection of The Golden Bull comprised of a 2:1 split from phenomenal producers Domaine Leroy and Domaine de la Romanée-Conti.[10]

OCTOBER

  • Berry Bros. & Rudd announced their first wine auction. Their new auction arm was launched this year, with their first auction showcasing predominantly Burgundian lots, from producers including Armand Rousseau, Georges Roumier, René Engel, Domaine de la Romanée-Conti and Domaine Dujac.
  • The 2024 Golden Vines Report showed a positive outlook for fine wine in 2025. Contributors to the report included 397 sommeliers and fine wine professionals, with over half suggesting either a ‘Positive’ or ‘Very Positive’ performance for the global fine wine industry next year. Further predictions included a greater interest in Italian fine wines.[11]

NOVEMBER

  • Il Marroneto Madonna delle Grazie tops wine-searchers ‘World’s Best Italians’ list. The list overall saw a substantial showing from smaller producers, not just Super-Tuscans, suggesting a broadening of the Italian fine wine market. [12]
  • Bull run fine wine landscape identified by Acker auction house. They reported a slowdown in sales activity, as well as a shift in market indicators, revealing a buying opportunity for investors.[13]

DECEMBER

  • Bitcoin surpasses $100,000 for the first time. Optimism surrounding the US President elect Donald Trump’s pledge to appoint crypto-friendly regulators saw the currency hit all-time highs.
  • Liv-ex Power 100 rankings revealed, with a Spanish winery topping the charts for the first time. Vega Sicilia took to top spot, with big gains also for Italian producers in the rankings.[14]
  • Liv-ex reported large gains in trade market share for Italy, as well as a strong showing from the US, Burgundy and the ‘rest of the world’.[15]As depicted below, the market shifts towards Italy and new world regions become clear when overlayed with Bordeaux year-on-year trade share decline.

Liv-ex regional breakdown of trade, 2013-24

LOOKING FORWARD

Contrasting investor confidence will play its part in the year ahead. Will the optimism felt by many in the US and Asia land at a level that will boost the less optimistic sellers in Europe? The spread between bid and offer in Q1 will be a key indicator as to how the year will unfold.

If we see more positivity in the US and Asia while seeing loses akin to the 1.7% decline of the leading benchmark LX100, its sharpest month-on-month decline since October 2023 (Q3 last year), we know that our selection process becomes even more important. As we have always selected wines from the very best available, 2025 will be a year where the already regimented criteria will need to become even more select, with more understanding of international markets, tastes and trends. Look out for our spotlight series focusing on the more prevalent wine loving cities, starting with NYC, in our Extraction reports.

Even in the less optimistic performance of the UK and European markets, some signs show we could return to growth soon. Value might be down but volume of sales is up and this demand will be a huge part of the market’s inevitable recovery. Regions to watch remain Tuscany, Piedmont, Napa Valley and smart buys in aged Bordeaux and undervalued Burgundy.

The challenges of a buyer’s market only pose opportunities for us as a company to show our clients the importance of experience and market knowledge, and the advice our portfolio managers can pass on. Our team is set to take on 2025.

Enzo Giannotta

Founder / Director
